instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
Got this board with water damage near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. 

Changed <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and some small components near that had wrong values. 


Now all main rails are ok, but all rails near efi chip are pulsing from 1.1 to 1.4 V. Board is trying to enter S0 and all S0 rails are pulsing (Ex: <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is pulsing 0.5-0.8.)


I tried new bios DUMP and same. Without bios it is pulsing too. Checked traces and all are ok. 


What else i can check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
Is not BIOS issue.
PCH doesn't access BIOS before <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?
Did you reball SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
SMC By pass not turning on

Right now trying reball smc because i see that also there is issue with <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>. Will back once finish

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message: Reballed and sames happening. Exactly same. Change SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and try again.
Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion; does it get pulse at pins 7 & 3?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  and pins 7 and 3 not pulsing. Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and the only difference is that after it is pulsin between 0.9 and 1.2


NO corrosion under <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, but changed it anyway, now <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing very lightly 0.00-0,002V ( dont know if this information is useful or not)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
Do you get pulse on all S3 and S0 power rails?
An o-scope can catch the faster peak pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
pp3v3 s3 and s0 are pulsing 0.5-0.8V and all other rails s0 and s3 pulsing too. 


Right now i am without o-scope :-(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
If trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly, you must be able to catch higher pulses.
Need to be sure which points have pulse or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message: "higher pulses" you mean the highest value of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> pulsing 1.1-1.4V
threads.message:
I'm talking about all power rails.
An o-scope can always catch the expected peak.
DC voltmeter will catch lower peaks, depending by the moment of the reading.
Repeated readings allow you to catch different values, some of them higher.
